centralQuestion: Should Massachusetts increase state funding for research if federal funding gets cut?

reasons.description: To avert immediate harm to Massachusetts’ research labs, jobs, and ongoing projects when federal grants are frozen or cut.

sources.title: Reuters: 'US judge blocks slashing of universities' federal funding, bars cuts to science foundation grants for now'
PBS NewsHour: 'Funding freeze could set research back years, Harvard scientists say'

reasons.description: To sustain Massachusetts’ innovation-driven economy and competitiveness; R&D strength underpins the state’s leadership and public investment can crowd in private R&D.

sources.title: Milken Institute: 'Massachusetts Is Best State for Technology and Science says Milken Institute'
OECD: 'Leveraging government R&D investment to boost private R&D investment in regions'

reasons.description: To retain researchers and prevent brain drain from Massachusetts institutions amid funding uncertainty.

sources.title: The Washington Post: 'Inside science labs trying to survive in the Trump era'
Politico: 'Red-state universities push back against funding cuts'

reasons.description: To pursue place-based, locally targeted investments that strengthen regional research clusters when national support wavers.

sources.title: Brookings Institution: 'Biden’s big bet on place-based industrial policy'

objections.description: State budgets face hard tradeoffs; increasing research funding could divert resources from core services or affordability priorities in higher education.

sources.title: Urban Institute: 'Higher education expenditures by state and local governments have grown as a share of general expenditures'
Associated Press: 'Pennsylvania House again fails to pass state subsidies for Penn State, Pitt, Temple'

objections.description: States risk inefficiently 'picking winners'; industrial-policy-style subsidies can be wasteful or distortive.

sources.title: American Enterprise Institute: 'Why industrial policy fails'
The Economist: 'Subsidies and protection will harm the world economy'

objections.description: Patchwork state funding can fragment efforts; priority should be restoring coherent federal support rather than duplicating it.

sources.title: Brookings Institution: 'A National Innovation Foundation: strengthening America’s innovation economy'
The Guardian: 'IMF warns subsidies risk “harmful competition” as governments embrace industrial policy'

research.title: 'Public R&D Investments and Private-sector Patenting: Evidence from NIH Funding Rules'
research.description: Analyzes quasi-experimental variation in NIH funding and finds that increases in public biomedical R&D spur additional private-sector patenting and estimated private value—evidence of positive spillovers.

research.title: 'The ripple effects of funding on researchers and output'
research.description: Shows that NIH grants generate broader 'ripple effects' through teams and trainees, increasing publications and research activity beyond the directly funded work.

research.title: 'Science, interrupted: Funding delays reduce research activity in NIH labs'
research.description: Examines how interruptions in NIH grant renewals lead labs to sharply reduce spending and activity, documenting short-run impacts of funding disruptions.

research.title: 'Comparison of Research Spending on New Drug Approvals by the US National Institutes of Health and the Pharmaceutical Industry'
research.description: Documents that NIH contributed to research associated with nearly all FDA-approved drugs from 2010–2019 and quantifies public spending across basic and applied phases using open data.

research.title: 'NIH funding for patents that contribute to market exclusivity of new drugs'
research.description: Assesses how often NIH-funded research leads to patents conferring market exclusivity for approved drugs, informing debates about public returns and translational pathways.
